description.narrative: On June 16, 2009, the government of Myanmar and China Power Investment Corporation signed a Memorandum of Agreement for the joint "Development, Operation and Transfer of the Hydropower Projects in Maykha, Malikha and Upstream of Irrawaddy-Myitsone River Basin". The biggest of these dams is Myitsone, or the confluence of the Maykha and Malikha rivers, which is expected to submerge more than 700 square kilometers of lands, and to relocate about 60 villages affecting approximately 15,000 people. The Myitsone dam controversy grew from a local into a national and even international issue leading President Thein Sein to suspend its construction in September2011. However, even before the suspension, residents of the four most affected villages surrounding thetwo rivers (Tanghpre, Mali Zup, Lahpre <(>&<)> Dawng Pan) had been forcibly relocated in the newly created village, Aung Myin Tha starting March 2013. The forced displacement and uprooting of the local population from the four low-lying villages has created alot of problems for the affected families, further deteriorating their already poor living conditions. Due to the sensitivity of the issue, very few development institutions supported the relocated families. Support came mostly from Asia World, (the organization behind the hydroelectric power project and receiving support from the China government), which has been limited and not enough to meet even the basic needs of the families. Considering the very difficult situation and the relatively small amounts of assistance being extended to the relocated families, Lahpai Seng Raw decided to commit the award money she received for being a 2013 Ramon Magsaysay awardee (Asia#s Nobel Prize) toserve as initial fund to support development projects in the confluence villages in Kachin. Being an awardee drove her more to continue with her advocacy of reaching out and making a difference in the lives of the most vulnerable and neglected in rural Myanmar. Lahpai Seng Raw immediately commissioned the conduct of participatory needs assessment in the confluence areas to identify priority projects. The assessment was conducted on September 19-29, 2013 in the 4 villages displaced by the dam construction including the relocation village, Aung Myin Tha. Results of the assessment revealed that the forced relocation had greatly aggravated the peoples# living conditions, thereby greatly reducing and even losing income from major livelihoods # farming, plantation crops, fishing and non-timber forest product collection. Peoplepredominantly depending on farming as a major source of livelihood and income lost their farms. And even the land surrounding their houses in the relocation site is of poor soil quality unfit for agricultural production. Inaddition, support from Asia World is unable to meet food needs. Considering the pervasive poverty, food insecurity and low income issues plaguing the families in the four most affected villages, sustainable livelihoods will be given high level of support in the proposed assistance.

participating-org.narrative:
Formed in erly 2014, Airavati is aptly named with the Sanskrit word for the great Irrawaddy/Ayeyarwady River that literally means Elephant River. Airavati denotes the huge River that flows for more than 2,000 kilometers from north to south through Myanmar. As Myanmar#s largest waterway, it originates in the Himalayas supporting a lucrative commercial industry and, more importantly, sustain livelihood of 20 million people living in the Ayeyarwady basin. Currently, this River is threatened by dams, pollution, civil unrestand climate change issues.
Airavati was created by a group of committed activists who want to ensure the river continues to flow freely far into the future, as well as preserving the environment, culture and the way of life for the many communities dependent on this lifeline, both in Kachin state and also further down the river. Lahpai Seng Raw, recipient of the Ramon Magsaysay Award 2013 from Myanmar, is part of this founding group and has donated her monetary award as seed funds for the organization, in keeping with her unwavering dedication to peace and development in Myanmar. These funds will support projects for the most marginalised people andcommunities in the watershed areas of the River displaced and threatened by a large dam project being built at the headwaters of the Ayeyarwady River.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: no. of women and men (small-scale crop farmers, cattle farmers, fisher folk) able to use sustainable production methods enabling them to better protect and use sustainably their livelihood resources
